title: Symmetrical Diagonal Stroke Contrast!
content:
What’s the “AM 1290” type?  
 [http://www.earthdayfairandexpo.org/Radio%20Disney%20Logo%202007.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20080906214334/http:/www.earthdayfairandexpo.org/Radio%20Disney%20Logo%202007.jpg "http://www.earthdayfairandexpo.org/Radio%20Disney%20Logo%202007.jpg")

Anybody know of any other fonts where the stroke  
contrast is laterally symmetrical in diagonals,  
instead of the conventional scheme?

hhp

 [‹ NEED HELP identifying a font](http://web.archive.org/web/20080906214334/http:/www.typophile.com/node/47933 "Go to previous forum topic") [Kooks ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080906214334/http:/www.typophile.com/node/47938 "Go to next forum topic")
author: hrant

comments.content:
That’s it! Thanks Brian.  
But I’m having trouble figuring out: Who made it, when?

And any others with that feature?

hhp

Check out the W in Garage Gothic:

[http://fontbureau.com/fonts/GarageGothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20080906214334/http:/fontbureau.com/fonts/GarageGothic "http://fontbureau.com/fonts/GarageGothic")

<cite>Who made it, when?</cite>

Monotype, in 1937/9, according to [Global Type](http://web.archive.org/web/20080906214334/http:/www.global-type.org/Searching.743.0.html).  
 [Ascender says](http://web.archive.org/web/20080906214334/http:/www.ascenderfonts.com/font/placard-condensed.aspx) it’s <cite>based on drawings received from Germany</cite>.

Thank you!

Germany, eh? Again. From the last years of the 19th century to WWII, Germany was doing more typographic innovation than every other country combined. You should see the sublime slanted-romans they made. Since WWII we don’t talk about that amazing spirit and its singular results any more.

hhp
